item.title: Help Command [317 PI]
item.dc:creator: @thakillah thakillah
item.description:
@thakillah wrote:

[quote=“neroxx, post:29, topic:509239”][quote author=thakillah link=topic=627481.msg4266960#msg4266960 date=1364154000]

Can i ask why did you do this?

FIRST I GAVE UP MY 745 SERVER NOW I GAVE UP MY 317 SERVER.
NOW I AM STARTING ON A 718!
745 DEVELOPMENT: 9 MONTHS!
317 DEVELOPMENT: 2 MONTHS!
718 DEVELOPMENT SO FAR: 1 MONTH AND 2 WEEKS.
NOW I HAVE ALMOST GIVED UP MY LIFE BECAUSE OF THESE RSPS, I AM TRYING TO MAKE MY RSPS ONLINE, BUT THE ONE WEEK AFTER “JAGEX HAS TAKEN OVER THIS PAGE” WTF IS THAT SOMEONE KILL JAGEX FOR ME??
NEVER LETTING ME MAKE MY OWN RSPS THATS THE SECOND REASON NOW SMD.

rivision 745 is not even out for 1.5 months and jagex cant edit any of your post your just a pathetic guy who thinks he is good
[/quote]He goes around boasting about that his good at programming, but when it comes to his servers, its crap. It’s also not true that he worked 9 months on a 745, and 2 months on a 317. He just use that numbers to make it be 10 months together, which is freakin much time… What people do for attention -.-[/quote]

I am actually developing my 718 for 8 months but this kid is talking about 745 and the 745 cache was released somewhere around january

Read full topic

item.title: Help Command [317 PI]
item.dc:creator: @runescape_sucks runescape sucks
item.description:
@runescape_sucks wrote:

Alright, I made a small program to test this:

public class Test { public static void main(String[] args) { for(int i1 = 0; i1 < 10; i1++) { if(i1 >= 1 && i1 <= 4) { System.out.println("My method: rights " + i1 + " true"); } else { System.out.println("My method: rights " + i1 + " false"); } } for(int i = 0; i < 10; i++) { if(i >= 1 || i <= 4) { System.out.println("Your method: rights " + i + " true"); } else { System.out.println("Your method: rights " + i + " false"); } } } }

And here was my result

My method: rights 0 false My method: rights 1 true My method: rights 2 true My method: rights 3 true My method: rights 4 true My method: rights 5 false My method: rights 6 false My method: rights 7 false My method: rights 8 false My method: rights 9 false Your method: rights 0 true Your method: rights 1 true Your method: rights 2 true Your method: rights 3 true Your method: rights 4 true Your method: rights 5 true Your method: rights 6 true Your method: rights 7 true Your method: rights 8 true Your method: rights 9 true

Read full topic

item.title: Help Command [317 PI]
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“runescape sucks, post:18, topic:509239”]Think about it, it can be either or. So technically speaking, it could range anywhere from rights -2147483648 to 2147483647

But if you used “if(c2.playerRights >=1 && c2.playerRights <= 3)” then it would allow from 1-3[/quote]
I have this code in my commands.java:
if (c.playerRights >= 8 || c.playerRights <= 15)
modCommands(c, playerCommand);
No normal player can use my mod commands…

Read full topic

item.title: Help Command [317 PI]
item.dc:creator: @runescape_sucks runescape sucks
item.description:
@runescape_sucks wrote:

Think about it, if you use “if(c2.playerRights >=1 || c2.playerRights <=3” it can be either or. So technically speaking, it could range anywhere from rights -2147483648 to 2147483647

But if you used “if(c2.playerRights >=1 && c2.playerRights <= 3)” then it would allow from 1-3

Read full topic

item.title: Help Command [317 PI]
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“runescape sucks, post:16, topic:509239”]I don’t think this is acceptable:
if(c2.playerRights >= 1 || c2.playerRights <= 3)
because it can be either greater than, or equal to, 1 or it can be less, or equal to,than 3

Use &&.[/quote]
Dude, that’s exactly what he wants. It allows only 1, 2, and 3 to be used.

Read full topic

item.title: Help Command [317 PI]
item.dc:creator: @runescape_sucks runescape sucks
item.description:
@runescape_sucks wrote:

I don’t think this is acceptable:
if(c2.playerRights >= 1 || c2.playerRights <= 3)
because it can be either greater than, or equal to, 1 or it can be less, or equal to,than 3

Use &&.

Read full topic

item.title: Help Command [317 PI]
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“noty, post:14, topic:509239”][quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=627481.msg4265969#msg4265969 date=1364061441]

if(c2.playerRights == 1 && c2.playerRights == 2 || c2.playerRights == 3)
can be:
if(c2.playerRights >= 1 || c2.playerRights <= 3)
Or even:
if(c2.playerRights >= 1)

Yeee, i know but the date i realsed this i was abit busy

Update the code then.
[/quote]
It’s almost the same, stop complaining, SON.[/quote]
No, actually. Your code checks if a player has BOTH playerRights 1 && playerRights 2. Which is impossible. Gj.

Read full topic
